attributes.title: Study 2
attributes.description: Second project aimed at eliciting behavioral effects of prestimulus cues during memory encoding.

q1.value: The effect of informative versus no pre-stimulus cues during encoding on recollection, familiarity, and source memory

q3.value:
There is a growing body of research indicating that neural activity before an experience can predict subsequent memory. These so-called 'pre-stimulus subsequent memory effects' - differences in neural activity preceded subsequently remembered and forgotten items - are thought to reflect proactive processes that benefit memory encoding and, specifically, mnemonic processes supporting recollection. However, it is unclear if the cognitive processes indexed in neuroimaging studies of pre-stimulus subsequent memory effects have corresponding behavioral correlates. The primary purpose of this study is to determine whether how pre-stimulus cues during memory encoding enhance subsequent memory performance. 

In a previous preregistered study (see https://osf.io/4whsm/) of this issue we did not find evidence supporting our hypothesis that informative pre-stimulus cues during memory encoding benefit subsequent memory performance. Participants in this first experiment incidentally encoded words for a later recognition memory test. Words at encoding were preceded by either informative or uninformative cues. Informative cues signaled which semantic judgment participants were to perform on the next word. Uninformative cues signaled an upcoming trial, but the semantic judgment to be made was only presented when the word appeared. The color of the cue or word dictate the semantic judgment (red: shoebox, blue: manmade). Relative to uninformative cues, pre-stimulus cues had no appreciable affect on overall memory performance (measured hits minus false alarm rates) nor on estimates of recollection and familiarity derived from fitting receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curves with the dual-process signal detection model. Do note that there was a significant effect of cue type on familiarity (p=0.048). However, a Bayesian paired t-test suggested that there was equivocal evidence for the null and alternative models (BF10=0.916). Thus, we believe this effect on familiarity was likely a false positive finding.

However, our previous study had a few limitations that may explain the lack of evidence for informative cues enhancing memory. For example, participants had to use different hands (i.e., right hand for manmade, left hand for shoebox) for the semantic judgments, which may have increased the demand on cognitive resources during the pre-stimulus interval. Increased demand on cognitive resources for processing pre-stimulus cues has been shown to eliminate ERP pre-stimulus subsequent memory effects (Galli et al., 2013, Cortex). It is quite possible that pre-stimulus cues simply recruit general attentional resources that are beneficial to memory encoding, and our inclusion of cues that are uninformative might not have been the appropriate control condition. Another possibility is that we did not use the appropriate measure of memory to elucidate pre-stimulus memory effects. Pre-stimulus memory effects are thought to reflect engagement of task-sets in line with upcoming cognitive goals. If this is the case, pre-stimulus cues might benefit subsequent memory performance for details consistent with the task set engaged. This might manifest as improved contextual memory for which of the two semantic judgments (shoebox vs. manmade) was performed at study. However, our first study used a subjective measure of memory that is essentially provides a ‘catch-all’ measure of recollection. Thus, this measure might not be able to capture recollection for experimentally defined contextual details that are affected by the inclusion of pre-stimulus encoding cues. 

This study was designed to address the above limitations from our first study and, we believe, to maximize the possibility that we observe pre-stimulus encoding cues affect subsequent recognition memory. As with the first study, participants will incidentally encode a list of words for a subsequent memory test. Participants make one of two semantic judgments (shoebox or manmade) for each word during the encoding phase. There are two different types of encoding blocks: cued and uncued. Words in cued blocks will be preceded by red or blue circle, with the color of the circle indicating which semantic judgment to make on the following word. In uncued blocks, no pre-stimulus cues will be presented. Instead, participants will be cued as to which semantic judgment to make by the color of a box the contains the to-be-judged word. At test, participants will make memory decisions using a 6-point confidence scale. For words attracting an 'old' response, participants will be asked to recall which semantic judgment they made about the word during the study phase. We will construct recognition memory receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curves with the confidence ratings at test, and subsequently estimate the contribution of recollection and familiarity with the dual-process signal detection (DPSD) model. The main dependent variables include study reaction times and measures of recognition memory accuracy at test (corrected hit rates, recollection and familiarity, source memory accuracy). 

Additionally, there is evidence that pre-retrieval processes, which are thought to behave similarly to processes elicited by pre-stimulus cues at encoding, vary with an individual's working memory capacity. The influence of working memory capacity on pre-stimulus memory effects has, to our knowledge, not been investigated. Thus, an additional exploratory aim of this study is to examine whether working memory capacity is associated with individual differences in benefits (or detriments) associated with pre-stimulus cues during memory encoding. We will measure working memory capacity using operation and spatial span tasks.

q4.value:
This experiment will test the hypothesis that informative pre-stimulus cues will affect memory performance. The following hypotheses will be tested:

(1) No directional prediction is made about the effect of pre-stimulus cues on overall recognition memory performance given that this measure is, in part, dependent on the relative contribution of recollection and familiarity to performance (Hypotheses #2, 3, and 4). 

(2) Based on findings from the neuroimaging literature linking pre-stimulus subsequent memory effects with recollection, we predict that estimates of recollection will be higher for studied words preceded by informative cues compared to words that have no pre-stimulus task cue. 

(3)  As with hypothesis #2, we predict greater source memory performance for studied words preceded by informative cues compared to words that have no pre-stimulus task cue. 

(4) The hypothesized effect of informative pre-stimulus cues on familiarity are less clear. As such, no specific directional prediction is made about this measure. 

(5) During study, reaction times (RTs) for the two semantic judgments will be faster for trials with informative pre-stimulus cues relative to trials with no cues.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
This is a repeated measures experimental design. The only manipulated variable of interest in this experiment is trial type, which has 3 levels: cued study item, uncued study item, and new item. 

The two types of old words (cued and uncued) will be presented during encoding in a blocked manner. There will be 2 blocks for cued trials and 2 blocks of uncued trials. The  four blocks will be counterbalanced using an ABBA/BAAB scheme (A-cued block, B-uncued block). 

Of note, the two semantic judgement during the study phase are also manipulated within-subjects (and specific to old items, but not new items). Although controlled by the experimenter, this variable will not be included in any analyses or hypothesis testing in this experiment.

q9.value: The critical words (those for the real study and test phases) will be randomized to the trial type factor anew for each participant.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will comprise young adults from the undergraduate population at the University of Notre Dame. Participants will be recruited through the online recruitment system (SONA) and will receive partial (or extra) course credit for their participation. To be included, participants must be between 18 and 30 years of age and report being a native English speaker (i.e., learned English prior to age 5). 

Participants will be excluded who are determined to not have understood the instructions (which is unexpected) will be excluded and replaced from the analysis. Participants who otherwise qualify and successfully complete the study may be excluded based on performance metrics (as described in the Data exclusion section of the Analysis Plan). These include low memory performance, high number of excluded trials, and failure to use the range of confidence responses. Participants excluded for any of these reasons will be replaced.

q13.value: The sample size will be 64 participants. Participants who volunteer from the study but have unusable data (i.e., low memory performance, high number of excluded trials, failure to use the range of confidence responses) will be replaced. These criteria are described in the Data exclusion section of the Analysis Plan.

q14.value: The sample size for this experiment was selected to be able to detect medium effect sizes. A 'sensitivity' power analysis was conducted using G*Power (v3.1.9.2) software. The analysis of the recognition memory data (i.e., corrected hit rates, recollection estimates, familiarity estimates, source memory performance) will be conducted with paired t-tests. The sample size of 64 allows for the detection of medium effect sizes (dz = 0.356) at 80% power and a two-tailed alpha of 0.05. The analysis of the study reaction time data will be conducted with a 2 (trial type: informed vs. no-cue) X 2 (memory: subsequent hit vs. miss) repeated measures ANOVA. For each cell in this design, the median RT will be used across all trials. Assuming an across-participant correlation of 0.50 for median RT in each cell, the sample size allows for the detection medium effect sizes (f = 0.147) at 80% power at p<0.05. Additionally, it should be noted that the a sample size of 64 is larger than prior studies that examined recognition memory performance for within-participant manipulations (e.g., Koen, Aly, Wang, and Yonelinas, 2013, Journal of Experimental Psychology: Learning, Memory, and Cognition) .

q15.value: There is no variable stopping rule. Data collection will stop when we reach 64 usable data sets (see Data Collection Procedure).

question.value: The primary variable being manipulated is trial type which has three levels (cued study item, uncued study item, new item).

There are 5 dependent variables that will be measured an analyzed for the critical hypotheses. 

(1) We will measure reaction times for both semantic judgments at study as a function of trial type (cued versus uncued) and subsequent memory (source hit, source miss, item miss).

(2) Overall recognition accuracy will be measured for each participant using corrected hit rates. The hit rate is the proportion of studied items receiving an 'old' response (i.e., a 4, 5, or 6 confidence response) and will be computed separately for cued and uncued condition. The false alarm rate is the proportion of new items at test receiving an 'old' response. The false alarm rate will be subtracted from both measures. (Note that for assessments of memory performance to meet inclusion criteria, this measure will also be calculated collapsed across cued and uncued trials).

(3 and 4) Estimates recollection (Ro) and familiarity (F) will be derived from the confidence data for each participant individually. Ro is measured as a probability ranging from 0 to 1, and F is measured as the discrimination index (d'). Note that F will be constrained to be positive (i.e., > 0). These measures will be derived by fitting the dual-process signal detection (DPSD) model to the receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curves formed by confidence rating data. This will be done for cued and uncued trials. The procedure for estimating these measures will follow the protocol outline in the ROC Toolbox for Matlab (https://github.com/jdkoen/roc_toolbox). Note that the DPSD model includes response criteria variables that will not be analyzed. Given the nature of the experimental design (e.g., two study item types, one new item type) the Ro and F parameters will be derived from a model that places an equality constraint on the response criteria parameters (i.e., c(i)) across the cued and uncued conditions.

(5) Source memory performance will be measured for each participant using a single high threshold model (Snodgrass and Corwin, 1988) taking into account the "guess" rate. Source memory will be measured from studied words attracting an 'old' response. This will be separately measured for words in the cued and uncued conditions. This source pR measure is calculated using the formula [pHit - .5*(1-pDK)]/[1 - .5*(1-pDK)], where pHit corresponds to the proportion of correctly identified old words attracting a correct source memory judgment and pDK reflects the proportion of correctly identified old words given a don't know response. 

Three additional dependent variables will be measured for exploratory analyses. These include:

(6 and 7) Working memory capacity will be measured with operation-span and symmetry span tasks. Operation and symmetry span scores will be computed using a partial score (i.e., summing the proportion of items recalled in a given set, regardless if the entire set was recalled) which is a common method for scoring operation and symmetry span tasks (Conway et al., 2005; Psychonomic Bulletin & Review). An example of partial credit scoring from Conway et al., (2005): (1 + .5 + 1+ 1 + 1 + 1+ .75 + .5 + .75 + .8 + .8 + .8) = 9.9/12 (83). Each number represents the proportion of correct responses within a span (e.g., recalling 2 elements from a 4 element item would count the same as recalling 3 elements from a 6 element item, or .50). Thus, the partial score is an average of these proportions. The span tasks will be administered using tatool (http://www.cognitivetools.uk/cognition/) that also includes a data analysis (R software) script for computing the partial scores. 

(8) A single composite score will then be created by averaging two operation and spatial spans (see Indices section below).

Reaction times for the informed and non-informed trials will be further divided by subsequent memory (source hit, source miss, and forget). Trials that subsequently attract an subsequent 'old' response (a 4, 5, or 6 confidence response) and an accurate source memory judgment (recalling the correct semantic judgement made during the study phase) will comprise the 'source hit' level, whereas trials that attract a subsequent 'old' response but receive an inaccurate or don't know source memory judgment will comprise the 'source miss' level. Trials attracting a subsequent 'new' response (a 1, 2, or 3 confidence response) will comprise the 'forget' level. Within each cell formed by the trial type and memory factors, the median reaction time (RT) across trials will be used as a summary measure for each participant. 

A composite working memory performance score will be calculated from the operation and symmetry span tasks. Working memory scores (i.e., partial scores) from both span tasks will be calculated and then z-score transformed and averaged together to create a single working memory composite score as previous work has done (Conway et al., 2005; Psychonomic Bulletin & Review, 2005, Gonthier, Thomassin, & Jean-Luc Roulin, 2015; Behavior Research methods, Ortells et al., 2016; Frontiers in Psychology).

Hypotheses #1-#4 will be tested by subjecting the corrected hit rates, recollection estimates, familiarity estimates, and source memory performance (source pR), respectively, to a paired-samples t-test. The factor in this analysis is trial type (informed versus no-cue trial). 

Hypothesis #5 will be tested by subjecting the median study reaction times (RTs) to a 2 (trial type: cued, uncued) X 3 (subsequent memory: source hit, source miss, forget) repeated measures ANOVA. Specifically, this hypothesis will be tested examining the main effect of trial type.

q21.value: Null-hypothesis significance testing  will be used with a standard threshold (p<0.05) for determining significant effects in all ANOVAs and paired t-tests (two-tailed).  Bayes factors will also be reported to evaluate evidence for the null and alternative models. While no absolute threshold is specified for Bayes factors, descriptive labels will follow the Bayes factor ranges outlined by Jeffreys (1961).

q22.value:
Participants can be excluded for three reasons based on task performance. First, participants will be excluded from the analysis if their overall memory performance is below a value of 0.10. This will be quantified using the proportion of hits minus the proportion of false alarms (both collapsed across confidence bins and study item condition) and source memory accuracy (i.e., source pR) below .05 (collapsed across study item condition). Second, participants who have more than 20% of the study trials excluded due to a failure to respond or entering multiple responses will be excluded from the analysis. Third, participants will be excluded if fewer than 10% of the confidence responses comprised the 2-5 response bins across all the valid test trials (i.e., old trials with a valid study response and all new trials). This criteria is meant to facilitate estimation of ROC parameters. Any participant excluded for one of the above reasons will be replaced until the final sample size is achieved. 

Participants will also be excluded due to low performance on the working memory tasks.  Specifically, participants may be excluded if they have below 80% accuracy on the processing task which is similar to prior work (Conway et al., 2005, Unsworth et al., 2005).  Accuracy for the processing task will be assessed by collapsing across the set sizes and span task (i.e., combining operation and symmetry span performance collapsed across set sizes).

q23.value: Missing data is not expected. Participants who do not fully complete the study will be excluded and replaced.

q24.value:
Exploratory analyses will be conducted on the study RT data, specifically to examine the main effects of subsequent memory and the trial type X subsequent memory interaction in the  2 (trial type) X 3 (subsequent memory) repeated measures ANOVA. Only Baye's factors will be reported for these tests. An interaction with with Moderate evidence (Baye's factor greater than or equal to 3 favoring the interaction term) will be further explored with post-hoc analyses. 

In addition, exploratory analyses will be conducted to relate measures of working memory capacity to performance on the reocgnition memory test. Given the exploratory nature of this aim of the experiment, the analyses are not fully specified. One exploratory analysis will be to correlate the three span measures with the difference between recognition memory performance on cued and uncued trials. Specifically, the span measures will be correlated with difference scores (cued-uncued) on the four measures of recognition memory performance (corrected hit rates, recollection estimates, familiarity estimates, and source pR). Only Baye's factors and associated correlation/regression coefficients will be reported for these tests.

Each number represents the proportion of correct responses within a span (e.g., recalling 2 elements from a 4 element item would count the same as recalling 3 elements from a 6 element item, or .50). Thus, the partial score is an average of these proportions. The span tasks will be administered using tatool (http://www.cognitivetools.uk/cognition/) that also includes a data analysis (R software) script for computing the partial scores. 

(8) A single composite score will then be created by averaging two operation and spatial spans (see Indices section below).
registration_responses.q18.question:
Reaction times for the informed and non-informed trials will be further divided by subsequent memory (source hit, source miss, and forget). Trials that subsequently attract an subsequent 'old' response (a 4, 5, or 6 confidence response) and an accurate source memory judgment (recalling the correct semantic judgement made during the study phase) will comprise the 'source hit' level, whereas trials that attract a subsequent 'old' response but receive an inaccurate or don't know source memory judgment will comprise the 'source miss' level. Trials attracting a subsequent 'new' response (a 1, 2, or 3 confidence response) will comprise the 'forget' level. Within each cell formed by the trial type and memory factors, the median reaction time (RT) across trials will be used as a summary measure for each participant. 

A composite working memory performance score will be calculated from the operation and symmetry span tasks. Working memory scores (i.e., partial scores) from both span tasks will be calculated and then z-score transformed and averaged together to create a single working memory composite score as previous work has done (Conway et al., 2005; Psychonomic Bulletin & Review, 2005, Gonthier, Thomassin, & Jean-Luc Roulin, 2015; Behavior Research methods, Ortells et al., 2016; Frontiers in Psychology).
registration_responses.q19.question:
Hypotheses #1-#4 will be tested by subjecting the corrected hit rates, recollection estimates, familiarity estimates, and source memory performance (source pR), respectively, to a paired-samples t-test. The factor in this analysis is trial type (informed versus no-cue trial). 

Hypothesis #5 will be tested by subjecting the median study reaction times (RTs) to a 2 (trial type: cued, uncued) X 3 (subsequent memory: source hit, source miss, forget) repeated measures ANOVA. Specifically, this hypothesis will be tested examining the main effect of trial type.

attributes.title: Electoral Effects of Development Aid: Experimental Evidence from Sierra Leone

q1.value: Electoral Effects of Development Aid: Experimental Evidence from Sierra Leone

q2.value: Kevin Grieco | Niccolo Meriggi | Maarten Voors

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: This study evaluates the electoral effects of a recent public health development intervention in Sierra Leone on the 2018 election results. We use election day exit poll surveys to test if voters reward politicians for development aid by comparing incumbent vote shares in villages that were randomly assigned to receive the aid intervention to incumbent vote shares in villages that were not assigned to receive the aid intervention.

q16.value: Hypothesis 1: Voters in villages that received the development intervention are more likely to vote for the incumbent candidate. Hypothesis 2a: Voters in treatment villages are more likely to vote for incumbent politicians when voters attribute the development project to the incumbent politician. Hypothesis 2b: Voters in treatment villages are more likely to vote for incumbent politicians when they perceive the development intervention has created a larger positive welfare shock.

q17.value: Hypothesis 1 is tested experimentally though the random assignment of development projects, where vote is measured at village level using exit poll surveys Hypothesis 2a and 2b are tested non-experimentally (heterogeneous effects) using survey data.

attributes.title: The Denial Induced Forgetting Effect and Spontaneous False Memory Formation

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: The Denial Induced Forgetting Effect and Spontaneous False Memory Formation

other.value:
Exploratory: 
Are there differences in belief for occurrence and recollection between the false denial and honest group? And are belief in occurrence and recollection affected differently for negative stimuli compared to neutral stimuli? 
Secondary Analyses: 
A 2 (condition: false denial vs honest) x 2 (Valence: negative vs neutral) mixed design with the latter being the within-subjects. The dependent variable being the scores of the belief of occurrence and recollection. We will use an analysis of variance for repeated measures on the belief of occurrence and recollection scores between the false denial and honest condition. If a statistically significant interaction is found, main effect analyses will be implemented. Additionally, we will calculate the Bayes factors for the effects of false denials on the belief of occurrence and recollection.

sample.value: Based on an a priori power analysis for a repeated measures and between factors analysis of variance (G*Power; Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, & Nuchner, 2007) with a power of 0.80 and a medium effect size of 0.25, a total sample size of 98 will be needed.

analyses.value: An analysis of variance for repeated measures between the false denial condition and honest condition on the dependent variables of recognition task will be performed. If a statistically significant interaction is found, main effect analyses will be implemented. Additionally, we will calculate the Bayes factors for the effects of false denials on true memory, spontaneous false memory, and incorrect memory.

outliers.value: No specific rules on outliers or excluding of data.

dependent.value:
The key dependent variable will be memory performance on the recognition task. Memory performance will be measured through:
1.true memory (recognizing what was previously studied/presented)
2.false memory (recognizing the critical lure of a DRM word list, a word highly related but not studied/presented; spontaneous false memory)
3.incorrect memory (incorrectly recognizing related/unrelated words that were not studied/presented, not lied about, and not a critical lure)

conditions.value: A 2 (condition: false denial vs honest) x 2 (Valence: negative vs neutral) mixed design with the latter factor as being within-subjects. Participants will be randomly assigned. Randomization is performed through Microsoft excel and is determined prior to the start of the experiment

hypothesis.value:
What is the effect of false denials on the susceptibility to spontaneous false memory formation? More specifically;
1.Falsely denying previously studied words on the combined Deese-Roediger-McDermott paradigm (DRM; Deese, 1959; Roediger & McDermott, 1995) and Amsterdam Short Term Memory task (ASTM; Schagen, Schmand, Sterke, & Lindeboom, 1997) will have memory undermining effects in the form of omission errors for those denied upon words.
2.We predict that the increase of omission errors will lower spontaneous false memory formation for the false denial condition compared to the honest condition.
3.Negative DRM word lists in the adapted DRM-ASTM paradigm will elicit more spontaneous false memories compared to neutral DRM word lists.

attributes.title: PREVALENCE OF ROOT CANAL ISTHMUS IN HUMAN PERMANENT TEETH USING MICRO CT- A SYSTEMATIC REVIEW
attributes.description: Root canal isthmus is defined as a channel or communication between two or more root canals that is often difficult to debride. Earlier studies classified the root canal isthmus into complete and incomplete. However, recent micro-computed tomography (micro-CT) studies have shown it to be more complex extending longitudinally. Hence there is a need for a review to understand the anatomy, to determine the prevalence of root canal isthmus, and also to assess the influence of various demographic factors on its prevalence.

q1.value: PREVALENCE OF ROOT CANAL ISTHMUS IN HUMAN PERMANENT TEETH USING MICRO-COMPUTED TOMOGRAPHY - A SYSTEMATIC REVIEW

q2.value: Professor Velmurugan Natanasabapathy, Sneha Susan Santosh, Aishwarya V, Sharath sundar mahendran, buvaneshwari , Venkateshbabu Nagendrababu

q4.value:
Prevalence and anatomy of root canal isthmus using Micro CT studies.
Age, gender and geographic location have no influence on the prevalence of isthmus.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

attributes.title: Latent network-class analysis with Gaussian graphical mixture model: An application to patients with depressive and anxiety disorders

summary.value:
■Post hoc changes in data analysis procedures
The data analysis procedures were slightly changed from those planned a priori and preregistered on OSF. First, when conducting LNCA, we entered factor scores that reflected the factor structure for each symptom measure (see the Measures subsection for details) instead of individual symptom items. This change was made after we found a technical error in conducting LNCA with individual symptom items, where the calculations failed to converge because of each item’s limited score range. Second, we additionally conducted LPA to discuss the similarities and differences between LNCA and LPA based on the empirical data. Third, we estimated partial correlation networks and calculated centrality indexes in addition to estimating networks with bi-directed edges computed in LNCA. We expected that partial correlation networks and centrality indexes would be more informative and potentially reveal richer clinical implications than networks with bi-directed edges alone.

name.value:
The Effects of Intentional Deception on Memory for False Event-Related Details:

The term of deception refers to any intended distortion of a self-report (Bass & Halligan, 2007).
In the forensic and legal context, people deceive in order to achieve personal benefits, both
financial – such as insurance compensation and disability pensions – and legal ¬ such as
reduced criminal responsibility (Jelicic, Merckelbach, & Boskovic, 2018). Most of the time,
people do so intentionally to convince others that their version of the events is true (Polage,
2004). An increasing wave of studies has investigated the effects of intentional deception on the original memory for events. For instance, in the forced confabulation paradigm (Ackil &
Zaragoza, 1998, 2011; Chrobak & Zaragoza 2008; Frost, Hanba & Zaragoza, 2007; Zaragoza,
Payment, Ackil, Drivdahl, & Beck, 2001), participants who were initially forced to falsely describe
details pertaining to a given event, were more likely to report such fabricated details in their final memory reports over time as compared with other participants who did not receive the same instruction. Indeed, a robust finding in such experimental situations is that forced fabrication leads to increasing the number of memory errors, although it does not seem to affect correct recollection for the event later on. Note that, in the forced confabulation paradigm, participants are explicitly instructed to come up with false details when interviewed. However, what would happen to the original memory for an event when individuals intentionally lie on fabricated postevent information? The idea of providing participants with erroneous post-event information finds its roots in the misinformation paradigm (e.g., Loftus, Miller, & Burns, 1978; McCloskey, & Zaragoza, 1985). That is, over the last four decades research has shown that when people receive misleading information after an event they tend to report that erroneous information in their memory for the original event. However, no research has investigated the effects of intentionally confirming such erroneous false details on genuine memory for an event, specifically when people are instructed to lie in order to achieve personal benefits. That will be the main focus of the present study. Namely, participants will be exposed to a case-vignette and, in order to receive financial compensation, some of them will be instructed to falsely confirming that certain false post-event details (not previously presented in the case-vignette) did occur. After a delay, these participants will be asked to tell the truth. Lying participants’ memory performance about the original case-vignette will be compared with truth-tellers and a control group of participants.

sample.value:
An a priori power analysis with a power of 0.80 and medium effect size (f=0.25) calculated using
G*Power (Faul, Erdfelder, Lan, & Buchner, 2007) indicates that a sample of 159 participants is
needed.

analyses.value:
A one-way Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) will be carried out to the test the effect of condition
(i.e., lying vs. truth-tellers vs. controls) on participants’ memory responses during the second
session (i.e., correct and false details).

outliers.value: Participants who do not comply with the instructions during session 1 (i.e., lying vs truth-telling) will be excluded from the data analysis.

dependent.value: The dependent variable will be both the amount of correct information reported and the number of false post-event details. Additionally, source monitoring responses and memory and beliefs rates will be assessed.

conditions.value: The study will use a 3 (Condition: lying vs. truth-telling vs. control) x 2 (Session: S1 vs. S2) mixed-model design, with the first factor manipulated as between-subjects.

hypothesis.value: Two possible outcomes might occur. On the one hand, participants initially instructed to lie on false post-event misinformation would be unable to detect discrepancies between the original case-vignette and those false details, which would make them more likely to report erroneous information over time (e.g., Loftus 2005) as compared with truth-tellers when both groups are invited to come forward with the truth. On the other hand, because lying participants might still remember both the case-vignette and what they prior lied about (Chrobak & Zaragoza 2008), they would report a similar number of postevent misinformation to truth-tellers during the final test. Moreover, although no statistically significant differences would be expected among the three different groups (i.e., lying, truth-telling and control) with respect to the correct information reported, both lying and truth-telling participants would report less false post-event misinformation than control (e.g., Loftus 2005).

attributes.title: Decider in Chief? Public Misperceptions about Presidential Power

q1.value: Decider in Chief? Public Misperceptions about Presidential Power

q2.value: Scott Clifford | D.J. Flynn | Brendan Nyhan

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: A growing literature examines misperceptions about public policy and politicians, but less is known about the prevalence or consequences of false or unsupported beliefs that people may hold about the American constitutional system. In this project, we examine misperceptions about presidential power. Citizens and journalists alike often credit or blame the president for many outcomes over which she has little to no control. In particular, presidents’ failure to overcome institutional obstacles such as partisan opposition in Congress is often attributed to their personal characteristics (e.g., the claim that Donald Trump failed to win over Republicans because he is unpersuasive). These misperceptions may be encouraged by media focus on personality narratives, politicians’ incentives to make grandiose promises on the campaign trail, and psychological tendencies to attribute behavior to internal dispositions rather than situational constraints (the “fundamental attribution error” -- see Jones and Nisbett 1971, Nisbett, Caputo, Legant, & Marecek 1973; but see Malle 2006). As a result, some people may have a stable tendency to attribute vast powers to the president consistent with the cultural mythology of presidential influence (Healy 2008) and to downplay institutional limitations on presidential power or control over events (e.g., Edwards 2003, 2012). However, beliefs about presidential power may interact with partisan motivated reasoning. Partisan supporters are motivated to believe that their candidates are responsible for good events, encouraging attributions of individual control, and not responsible for bad events, encouraging situational (or institutional) attributions of control. Partisan opponents, of course, are motivated to believe the opposite. As a result, beliefs about presidential power may shift in response to changes in the political environment, such as the partisanship of the president. To test these hypotheses, we conduct a survey experiment embedded in a panel study. The experiment focuses on a recent presidential policy failure and randomizes whether the failure is attributed to institutional constraints or the president’s personal qualities (or no attribution). This design allows us to test whether beliefs about presidential power shift in response to policy failures and media frames about the causes of the failure. Additionally, the design allows us to test whether these effects are moderated by prior beliefs about presidential power and by prior attitudes towards the president (both measured in prior waves). (In previous exploratory research, we contrasted data from a multi-wave panel survey with a survey of scholarly experts recruited from the APSA Presidency & Executive Politics section to measure the prevalence of misperceptions about presidential power and control over political and economic outcomes.)

q16.value: H1: Respondents who perceive high levels of presidential power will rate personal barriers to Donald Trump achieving his goals as greater and institutional barriers as weaker than those who perceive low levels of presidential power. H2: Following a policy failure, perceptions of presidential power will decline more among respondents who support Trump than among respondents who oppose Trump. H3a: Exposure to a frame attributing Trump's failures to his personal characteristics and behavior will increase the perceived importance of personal factors in determining the success of a president and decrease the perceived importance of institutional factors (relative to a baseline condition in which no explanation is provided). H3b: These effects will be larger among Trump opponents than among Trump supporters. H3c: Among respondents who perceive high levels of presidential power, these effects will be larger among Trump opponents than among Trump supporters. H4a: Exposure to a frame attributing Trump's failures to institutional constraints will decrease the perceived importance of personal factors in determining the success of a president and increase the perceived importance of institutional factors (relative to a baseline condition in which no explanation is provided). H4b: These effects will be larger among Trump supporters than among Trump opponents. H4c: Among respondents who perceive low levels of presidential power, these effects will be larger among Trump supporters than among Trump opponents. We also consider the following research questions where we have weaker theoretical priors. RQ1: Among Trump supporters, we will examine whether exposure to a frame attributing Trump's failures to his personal characteristics and behavior increases the perceived importance of personal factors in determining the success of a president and decreases the perceived importance of institutional factors more (relative to a baseline condition in which no explanation is provided) among those who perceive high levels of presidential power than those who perceive low levels of presidential power. RQ2: Among Trump opponents, we will examine whether exposure to a frame attributing Trump's failures to institutional constraints decreases the perceived importance of personal factors in determining the success of a president and increases the perceived importance of institutional factors more (relative to a baseline condition in which no explanation is provided) among those who perceive low levels of presidential power than those who perceive high levels of presidential power. RQ3: We will consider whether the exposure to the personal and institutional attribution frames affects perceptions of Trump’s traits, job approval, favorable ratings, and perceived ideology (relative to a baseline condition in which no explanation is provided). RQ4: We will consider whether the manipulation affects attributions of political conflict and dysfunction to the kinds of people who serve versus the configuration of institutions and political context in which they serve.

q17.value: [The study protocol is attached.] Eligibility and exclusion criteria for participants Participants will be members of an existing Mechanical Turk panel who are United States residents age 18 or older. We will invite all participants who completed three previous survey waves that measured their demographic characteristics; political beliefs, attitudes, and knowledge; and beliefs about presidential control (878 individuals completed all three surveys). Prior to beginning the experiment, participants will be provided with a description of the study and reminded that participation is voluntary and that they are free to withdraw at any time. Participants will then be asked to indicate whether they agree to participate in the study. Respondents will receive a full debriefing at the conclusion of the study. Amazon does not provide any identifiable information to the investigators about the study participants, nor will we ask about any identifying information. The nature of data to be obtained: We will collect individual-level survey data, including questions about demographic/political characteristics and people’s political beliefs and opinions. Randomization approach Participants in this wave of our panel will be randomly assigned with 1/3 probability to a control condition, to a condition attributing Donald Trump’s failures to his personal behavior and characteristics, or to a condition attributing Donald Trump’s failures to opposition from Congress. This randomization will be carried out in the Qualtrics survey platform. Data collection and blinding All data will be collected online on the Qualtrics survey platform. Primary and secondary outcome measures Before measuring our primary outcome variables (see below), we will re-measure respondents’ beliefs about presidential power and presidential control over various outcomes, which were asked previously in waves 2 and 3. We ask these questions again here to assess the extent of stability in perceptions about presidential power and control across changes in the political environment. Presidential control over outcomes on a five-point scale where 5=total control: -The price of gasoline -The inflation rate -The level of civility in Washington, DC -The amount of gridlock in Congress Statements about presidential power where 4=very accurate for non-starred items and 4=not at all accurate for starred items: -There are no limits to what a president can achieve if he or she uses the powers of his/her office effectively. -Members of Congress can easily resist pressure from the president and vote how they choose.* -Partisanship makes it difficult for any president to achieve consensus on a controversial policy issue.* -Without large partisan majorities in Congress, most presidents will struggle to pass their agenda.* -Gridlock in Congress is typically the result of a failure of presidential leadership. -If a president doesn’t follow through on a campaign promise, it’s probably because they didn’t really want it to happen. These scales have been previously tested so we will take the mean of each after reverse-coding (four-point scale for power, five-point for control). After a distracter task, respondents will answer our primary outcome measures, which focus on attributions for Donald Trump’s failure on health care policy. These questions ask respondents to indicate the perceived accuracy of the following statements on a four-point accuracy scale from very accurate to not at all accurate. The first battery focuses on institutional barriers to Trump’s health care bill while the second focuses on personality or tactical barriers. The order in which respondents answer each battery -- and the order of statements within each battery -- will be randomized. The divisions in Congress would have made it nearly impossible for any president to pass a health care bill. As president, Trump has relatively little leverage over Congress, making it difficult to pass his health care bill. Public opinion was a major obstacle to passing the health care bill Trump supported. Opposition from outside groups helped kill the health care bill Trump supported. The balance of power in Washington made it extremely difficult for Trump to enact the health care bill. Trump could have overcome opposition to his health care bill in Congress if he had made a stronger and more persuasive case. If Trump were a true leader, he would have convinced Congress to support his health care bill. The public could have been convinced to support the health care bill if Trump had more effectively shaped the debate over the issue. If Trump tried harder, he would have been be able to pass his health care bill. Trump’s personality is preventing him from leading more effectively in the debate over his health care bill. The four items that make internal attributions will be coded so that 1=not at all accurate and 4=very accurate, while the external attributions will be coded so that 1=very accurate and 4=not at all accurate. The outcome measures will thus take higher values when respondents make internal attributions and lower values when they make external ones. We will take the mean of these ten outcome measures. If the items used for this measure scale together using principal component analysis, we will create a composite measure of Trump attributions and use it as our primary outcome measure. If the two subscales each scale together rather than as a single scale, we will consider Trump external attributions and internal attributions as separate outcome measures instead. If none of the items scale together well, we will analyze responses to each question separately. We will also exclude items that do not clearly load on a single scale. (Note: Though we will analyze the component questions of our primary outcome measure using principal component analysis, we will construct any combined outcome measure as means for ease of interpretation.) We will also consider the following secondary outcome measures. We will measure perceptions of Trump’s traits (ratings on a 1-5 scale where 5=extremely well and 1=not at all well), job approval (on a 1-4 scale where 4=strongly approve), favorable ratings (on a 1-5 scale where 5=very favorable), and perceived ideology (on a 1-7 scale where 1=extremely liberal and 7=extremely conservative). We will consider each separately. Another set of questions will consider agreement with a series of statements that attribute political problems and outcomes to the types of people in office or the institutions and political context in which they serve (1-4 scale where 1=not at all accurate and 4=very accurate). The dysfunction in Washington could be solved if we had the right people in office. The average American could do a better job than most politicians. Any president will struggle when their party does not control Congress. No president can end gridlock or break polarization. If the items used for this measure scale together using principal component analysis, we will create a composite measure of attributions about political dysfunction using a simple mean after reverse-coding. We will exclude items that do not clearly load on the scale. If none of the items scale together well, we will analyze responses to each item separately. Finally, we include a binary measure that captures respondents’ perceptions of the relative importance of personal versus institutional factors in determining Trump’s ability to carry out his campaign promises. If you had to pick one, what do you think is the biggest barrier to Donald Trump successfully carrying out his campaign promises? -His behavior and personal characteristics -Opposition in Congress Statistical analyses All results will be estimated using OLS with robust standard errors and verified for robustness using appropriate GLM estimators (see below). We exclude control variables in our experimental analyses (see below). Finally, we split Trump supporters from opponents using a binary indicator for support reflecting job approval in the top two categories on a four-point approval scale (opponents are the omitted category). If the items used for this measure scale together using principal components factor analysis, we will create a composite measure of presidential attributions as a factor score and use it as our primary outcome measure. If the two subscales each scale together, we will consider presidential control and presidential power as separate independent variables, estimate factor scores for each, and run separate models for each in the analyses specified below. We will exclude items that do not clearly load on a single scale. Because this is an observational analysis, we include controls for gender, age, race, and education. H3b: These effects (personal frame) will be larger among Trump opponents than among Trump supporters. H4b: These effects (institutional frame) will be larger among Trump supporters than among Trump opponents. reg Y personal institutional support personal*support institutional*support, robust H3c: Among respondents who perceive high levels of presidential power, these effects (personal) will be larger among Trump opponents than among Trump supporters. Notes: -For interaction terms, scales, and moderators, if results are consistent using a median/tercile split or indicators rather than a continuous scale, we may present the latter in the main text for ease of exposition and include the continuous scale results in an appendix. We will compute all marginal effects appropriate to test the hypotheses of interest from the models described below. We will also use tercile indicators to test whether the linearity assumption holds for interactions per Hainmueller et al (N.d.) and replace the continuous interactions in our models with them if it does not. -We will compute and report appropriate auxiliary quantities from our models, including treatment effects by subgroup and differences in marginal effects between subgroups. -We will compute all marginal effects appropriate to test the hypotheses of interest from any interaction models. In some cases, we may present treatment effects estimated on different subsets of the data for expositional clarity. If so, we will verify that we can reject the null of no difference in treatment effects in a more complex interactive model reported in an appendix when possible. -We will also compute and report summary statistics for our samples. We will also collect and may report response timing data as a proxy for respondent attention. -The order of hypotheses and analyses in the final manuscript may be altered for expositional clarity. -Where applicable, regression results for binary dependent variables will be verified for robustness using probit. Regression results for individual ordered dependent variables will be verified for robustness using ordered probit. -We may estimate the experimental models described above with a standard set of covariates (indicators for gender, age groups, race, a four-year college degree, and their score on a standard political knowledge scale) if including those has a substantively important effect on the precision of our treatment effect estimates. In that case, however, both models will be reported.

registration_responses.q1: Decider in Chief? Public Misperceptions about Presidential Power
registration_responses.q2: Scott Clifford | D.J. Flynn | Brendan Nyhan
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data
registration_responses.q15: A growing literature examines misperceptions about public policy and politicians, but less is known about the prevalence or consequences of false or unsupported beliefs that people may hold about the American constitutional system. In this project, we examine misperceptions about presidential power. Citizens and journalists alike often credit or blame the president for many outcomes over which she has little to no control. In particular, presidents’ failure to overcome institutional obstacles such as partisan opposition in Congress is often attributed to their personal characteristics (e.g., the claim that Donald Trump failed to win over Republicans because he is unpersuasive). These misperceptions may be encouraged by media focus on personality narratives, politicians’ incentives to make grandiose promises on the campaign trail, and psychological tendencies to attribute behavior to internal dispositions rather than situational constraints (the “fundamental attribution error” -- see Jones and Nisbett 1971, Nisbett, Caputo, Legant, & Marecek 1973; but see Malle 2006). As a result, some people may have a stable tendency to attribute vast powers to the president consistent with the cultural mythology of presidential influence (Healy 2008) and to downplay institutional limitations on presidential power or control over events (e.g., Edwards 2003, 2012). However, beliefs about presidential power may interact with partisan motivated reasoning. Partisan supporters are motivated to believe that their candidates are responsible for good events, encouraging attributions of individual control, and not responsible for bad events, encouraging situational (or institutional) attributions of control. Partisan opponents, of course, are motivated to believe the opposite. As a result, beliefs about presidential power may shift in response to changes in the political environment, such as the partisanship of the president. To test these hypotheses, we conduct a survey experiment embedded in a panel study. The experiment focuses on a recent presidential policy failure and randomizes whether the failure is attributed to institutional constraints or the president’s personal qualities (or no attribution). This design allows us to test whether beliefs about presidential power shift in response to policy failures and media frames about the causes of the failure. Additionally, the design allows us to test whether these effects are moderated by prior beliefs about presidential power and by prior attitudes towards the president (both measured in prior waves). (In previous exploratory research, we contrasted data from a multi-wave panel survey with a survey of scholarly experts recruited from the APSA Presidency & Executive Politics section to measure the prevalence of misperceptions about presidential power and control over political and economic outcomes.)
registration_responses.q16: H1: Respondents who perceive high levels of presidential power will rate personal barriers to Donald Trump achieving his goals as greater and institutional barriers as weaker than those who perceive low levels of presidential power. H2: Following a policy failure, perceptions of presidential power will decline more among respondents who support Trump than among respondents who oppose Trump. H3a: Exposure to a frame attributing Trump's failures to his personal characteristics and behavior will increase the perceived importance of personal factors in determining the success of a president and decrease the perceived importance of institutional factors (relative to a baseline condition in which no explanation is provided). H3b: These effects will be larger among Trump opponents than among Trump supporters. H3c: Among respondents who perceive high levels of presidential power, these effects will be larger among Trump opponents than among Trump supporters. H4a: Exposure to a frame attributing Trump's failures to institutional constraints will decrease the perceived importance of personal factors in determining the success of a president and increase the perceived importance of institutional factors (relative to a baseline condition in which no explanation is provided). H4b: These effects will be larger among Trump supporters than among Trump opponents. H4c: Among respondents who perceive low levels of presidential power, these effects will be larger among Trump supporters than among Trump opponents. We also consider the following research questions where we have weaker theoretical priors. RQ1: Among Trump supporters, we will examine whether exposure to a frame attributing Trump's failures to his personal characteristics and behavior increases the perceived importance of personal factors in determining the success of a president and decreases the perceived importance of institutional factors more (relative to a baseline condition in which no explanation is provided) among those who perceive high levels of presidential power than those who perceive low levels of presidential power. RQ2: Among Trump opponents, we will examine whether exposure to a frame attributing Trump's failures to institutional constraints decreases the perceived importance of personal factors in determining the success of a president and increases the perceived importance of institutional factors more (relative to a baseline condition in which no explanation is provided) among those who perceive low levels of presidential power than those who perceive high levels of presidential power. RQ3: We will consider whether the exposure to the personal and institutional attribution frames affects perceptions of Trump’s traits, job approval, favorable ratings, and perceived ideology (relative to a baseline condition in which no explanation is provided). RQ4: We will consider whether the manipulation affects attributions of political conflict and dysfunction to the kinds of people who serve versus the configuration of institutions and political context in which they serve.

attributes.title: Perceived Psychological Safety and Learning-Promoting Behaviors of Working Students: The Mediating Role of Error Orientation

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Perceived Psychological Safety and Learning-Promoting Behaviors of Working Students: The Mediating Role of Error Orientation

sample.value: With regards to the number of items in our questionnaire and the planned statistical analysis, the sample size is going to consist of at least 210 participants. The calculation of the sample size is based on a rule of having at least five participants per item in the questionnaire.

analyses.value: We will test whether the assumptions for a path analysis are met before we perform it in AMOS in order to test the hypothesized relationships.

dependent.value:
Learning-promoting behaviors: reflective activity and type of feedback seeking

Reflective activity: The reflection subscale of the competence-reflection-inventory (Kauffeld, Grote, & Henschel, 2007) will be used. Participants will be asked to indicate on a 6-point Likert scale the extent to which they agree with four statements relating to individual reflective activity.

Type of feedback seeking: A scale by Janssen and Prins (2007) consisting of the two subscales seeking of self-improvement information and seeking of self-validation information will be used. Participants will be asked to indicate on a 5-point Likert scale the extent to which they agree with the statements providing reasons for which they might seek feedback at work. 

Additionally, demographic variables will be collected: age, gender, organizational tenure, years of work experience, educational background, and field of studies. Out of these variables, age, gender and organizational tenure will be included as covariates.

conditions.value: Based on their native language, participants will be assigned to either a Swedish or a German version of the questionnaire.

hypothesis.value:
Main question: Does error orientation mediate the relationship between perceived psychological safety and the two learning-promoting behaviors (a) reflective activity and (b) type of feedback seeking in working students?

Hypothesis 1: Perceived psychological safety is positively related to (a) learning from errors orientation and negatively related to (b) orientation toward covering errors and to (c) avoidant error orientation in working students.

Hypothesis 2a: Learning from errors orientation in working students is positively related to (a) reflective activity and (b) the seeking of self-improvement information; and negatively to (c) the seeking of self-validation information.

Hypothesis 2b: Avoidant error orientation in working students  is positively related to (a) the seeking of self-validation information and negatively to (b) reflective activity.

Hypothesis 2c: An orientation toward covering errors in working students is negatively related to (a) reflective activity and (b) the seeking of self-improvement information.

Hypothesis 3a: Learning from errors orientation mediates the relationship between perceived psychological safety and (a) reflective activity, (b) the seeking of self-improvement information, and (c) the seeking of self-validation information in working students.

Hypothesis 3b: Avoidant error orientation mediates the relationship between perceived psychological safety and (a) reflective activity and (b) the seeking of self-validation information in working students.

Hypothesis 3c: An orientation toward covering errors mediates the relationship between perceived psychological safety and (a) reflective activity and (b) the seeking of self-improvement information in working students.

Based on previous research, the variables age, gender and organizational tenure are expected to influence the relationship between perceived psychological safety and the two learning-promoting behaviors. Therefore, these variables will be included as covariates.

registration_responses.data: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.
registration_responses.name: Perceived Psychological Safety and Learning-Promoting Behaviors of Working Students: The Mediating Role of Error Orientation
registration_responses.sample: With regards to the number of items in our questionnaire and the planned statistical analysis, the sample size is going to consist of at least 210 participants. The calculation of the sample size is based on a rule of having at least five participants per item in the questionnaire.
registration_responses.analyses: We will test whether the assumptions for a path analysis are met before we perform it in AMOS in order to test the hypothesized relationships.
registration_responses.dependent:
Learning-promoting behaviors: reflective activity and type of feedback seeking

Reflective activity: The reflection subscale of the competence-reflection-inventory (Kauffeld, Grote, & Henschel, 2007) will be used. Participants will be asked to indicate on a 6-point Likert scale the extent to which they agree with four statements relating to individual reflective activity.

Type of feedback seeking: A scale by Janssen and Prins (2007) consisting of the two subscales seeking of self-improvement information and seeking of self-validation information will be used. Participants will be asked to indicate on a 5-point Likert scale the extent to which they agree with the statements providing reasons for which they might seek feedback at work. 

Additionally, demographic variables will be collected: age, gender, organizational tenure, years of work experience, educational background, and field of studies. Out of these variables, age, gender and organizational tenure will be included as covariates.

q3.value: An important component of studying chronic illness communities is understanding how they seek social support. Traditionally, this support has come from family, friends, or others nearby with their condition. However, it may be difficult to find those with similar experiences, and children with chronic illness tend to feel more isolated than their peers. Social media has opened up a whole new world for chronic illness communities where people can connect with others across the world who share the same experience they do. The purpose of our study is to explore Type I diabetes communities on Twitter to gain a better understanding of what topics are being talked about, what types of people are active community member, and whether connections between people are associated with their roles in the community and/or the subject matter of their tweets.

q4.value: Since this study is exploratory in nature we will refrain from making specific hypothesis. Our primary research questions are as follows. What do people talk about on Twitter regarding Type 1 Diabetes? Who is talking about Type 1 Diabetes? What is the structure of the network of people talking about Type 1 Diabetes?

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We will scrape our data from Twitter using the Rtweet package.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

question.value: Our initial scrape will be limited to the most recent 1500 tweets (from the past seven days) that include one of the following hashtags: #t1d, #t1dlookslikeme, #brokenpancreas, #type1kid, #invisibleillness, #typeonetypenone, #diabadass, #type1warrior, #beyondtype1, #insulindependent, #typeonestrong, #dexcom, #GBDoc. We will filter those initial 1500 tweets for unique Twitter accounts. Then we will pull the most recent 100 Tweets from each of those accounts and filter for users who have used at least one of the hashtags listed above on three separate days. Then we will pull the followers (up to 5000) for each community member identified in the previous step. Finally, we will pull the most recent 100 tweets for each follower and filter for users who have used at least one of the hashtags listed above on three separate days. These two samples will be combined to form our Type 1 Diabetic twitter community. See attached code.

q13.value: Our initial sample size will be limited to 1500, this will expand to an unknown sample size as we collect historical tweets for initial community members and their followers. Based on tests of our script (searching for tweets associated with the deaf community) we estimate that we'll collect data from approximately 8,000 users, totaling around 740,000 tweets.

q14.value: This initial sample size allows our Type 1 Diabetic Twitter network to expand in subsequent data collection steps to a size that is still able to be processed by a single computer.

question.value: Tweets, individual words in Tweets and the frequency of their use by each account, Twitter accounts, followers of Twitter accounts, sentiment, emotion, Twitter bio categories. Sentiment refers to the positive or negative valence of a word (line 68-80) and emotion refers to the degree to which a word emotes anger, anticipation, disgust, fear, joy, sadness, surprise, and/or trust (line 101-109)

Latent dirchlet analysis will be used to estimate the number and content of topics. 

To explore who is talking about Type 1 Diabetes on Twitter we will categorize the type of Twitter user based on their Twitter account biography. We will utilize name, profile picture, and tweets as necessary for additional information. Research assistants will be asked to give a free response category for a small portion of Twitter accounts in order to determine a set of user categories which will then be applied to the remaining Twitter accounts.

To understand what topics the Type 1 Diabetic community is discussing on Twitter, we will first look at a bar graph of the most popular words. We will then do a sentiment and emotion analysis using the NRC Twitter dictionaries. We will compare these analyses to a random sample of Tweets. Finally, we will use Latent Dirichlet Allocation at the tweet level to model latent topics in our data. We will determine the appropriate number of topics based on perplexity and topic coherence. We will determine labels for these latent topics by looking at top terms for each topic (per-topic-per-word probabilities), terms that have the greatest difference in beta weight between topics, terms that weight heavily on a given topic (per-document-per-topic probabilities). 

To explore the network structure of our Type 1 Diabetes community sample we will use social network analysis. In this analysis, each node will represent a Twitter account and each directed edge will represent a follow. Each node will be colored based on the user category determined in the previous analysis. An alternate graph will color each node based on the topic category determined in our Latent Dirichlet Allocation analysis. At first, we will use only unique users from our initial Tweet pull.  We then plan to expand this analysis to include followers of those initial users based on graph interpretability. 

All analyses above are exploratory.

q22.value: In our data pull we will exclude participants that have not used one of the listed hashtags on at least three separate days. When cleaning our tweets for analysis we will remove links, &, the less than symbol, the greater than symbol, RT, stop words and hashtags used in our initial data pull.  For our sentiment analysis, we will also remove Type 1 Diabetic and medical words that are being interpreted as having a sentiment (positive or negative) rather than being neutral.
